entry.def: A significant amount or effect is large enough to be important or affect a situation to a noticeable degree.

example.ex: A small but significant number of 11-year-olds are illiterate.
example.tran: 数量不多但仍有相当一部分 11 岁孩子是文盲。

example.ex: ...foods that offer a significant amount of protein...

entry.def: A significant fact, event, or thing is one that is important or shows something.

example.ex: Time would appear to be the significant factor in this whole drama.
example.tran: 时间似乎是整部剧中一个举足轻重的因素。

entry.tran: 别有含义的;意味深远的
entry.def: A significant action or gesture is intended to have a special meaning.

example.ex: Mrs Bycraft gave Rose a significant glance.
example.tran: 拜克拉夫特夫人意味深长地瞥了罗丝一眼。

sentences.sentence: "our budget will be significantly affected by these new cuts"

means.word_mean: 3. in an important way or to an important degree;

sentences.sentence: "more importantly, Weber held that the manifold meaning attached to the event by the social scientist could alter his definition of the concrete event itself"

Sentence.sentence: While the emphasis on teaching to higher, test-driven standards as set in No Child Left Behind resulted in significantly better performance in elementary(and some middle)schools, high schools for a variety of reasons seemed to have made little progress.

sentences.en: Most people have speech, but significantly fewer have writing.
sentences.cn: 大多数人都能说，但能写的人就少多了。

sentences.en: Eating a good diet significantly lessens the risk of heart disease.
sentences.cn: 良好的饮食习惯能大大减少患心脏病的机率。

sentences.en: Eating garlic can significantly reduce cholesterol in the blood.
sentences.cn: 吃大蒜可以大大减少血液中的胆固醇。

sentences.en: Even last year the nation’s eating habits changed significantly.
sentences.cn: 就在去年，该国的饮食习惯发生了重大变化。
